channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: Israel strikes Iran and braces for retaliation
item.description: Israel launched an airstrike on Iran overnight. Blasts were heard in the capital Tehran around 3am local time. Israel's defense ministry warned it expects missile and drone retaliation.

item.title: House narrowly passes bill to claw back $1.1 billion from public media
item.description: The House of Representatives voted to claw back two years of federal funding for public broadcasting Thursday in a largely party line vote. The bill heads to the Senate next.

item.title: What's behind the rise in wearable health tracking devices
item.description: NPR's Ailsa Chang talks with Adam Clark Estes of Vox about his new story out titled: "I Covered my body in health trackers for 6 months. It ruined my life."

item.title: This week in science: humans' unique breathing, droughts and the diets of dinosaurs
item.description: Regina Barber and Rachel Carlson of Short Wave talk about humans' unique breathing patterns, how a hotter planet worsens droughts, and the diets of dinosaurs.

item.title: This California block tried to quit fossil fuels. Here's what they learned
item.description: A project spearheaded by UC Berkeley researchers provides free electric appliances and solar panels to people. In exchange, researchers learn what works in an attempt to electrify on a larger scale.

item.title: DHS official says immigration raids in LA will continue, despite the ongoing protests
item.description: NPR's Ailsa Chang talks with assistant Secretary for Border and Immigration Policy Tony Pham â€” also a former acting director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, or ICE.

item.title: Sen. Padilla was removed from DHS presser and briefly handcuffed
item.description: California Sen. Alex Padilla was forcibly removed from the press conference after entering the room and trying to speak with the Secretary of Homeland Security.

item.title: Online sales of obesity drug alternatives carry on despite FDA deadlines
item.description: Since the FDA said shortages of Wegovy and Zepbound are over, compounding pharmacies are supposed to stop making copies of the drugs. But some of those business are trying to find ways to continue.

item.title: Republican efforts to cut green energy credits meets resistance in the Senate
item.description: A small number of Senate Republicans are pushing back on their own party's plans to cut green energy credits that were approved under former President Biden.

item.title: Saturday's military parade will be the first in D.C. since 1991's Victory Celebration
item.description: The last time the United States held a national military parade was in June 1991, timed to welcome returning veterans of the 100-day Persian Gulf War.
